completedText: Congratulations! You found and learned about the 9 Bathroom Triggers and Ways to Avoid!! Now you are going into the Kitchen. Enjoy finding and learning!!

postText:
Molds, fungi, or spores that live on surfaces are sometimes so tiny they can’t be seen with the eye. They can go into the air and be breathed in.

  • Mold can cause asthma to flare for some people.

  • Mold grows in damp areas with high humidity.

  • Common areas where mold grows are: bathrooms, basements, potted plants, and areas of indoor water leaks.

 

Mold: How to avoid or reduce this trigger:

  • Open the door, windows, or use a fan to remove steam.

  • Keep indoor humidity under 50%.

  • Use a dehumidifier.

  • Wipe down and dry the shower area. Clean shower curtains to remove mold.
targets.Name: BathtubMold
targets.hint: If you let water drip, I can grow

targets.Name: Cat
postText:
Furry Pets like dogs, cats, hamsters, guinea pigs, and rabbits are common allergens that can trigger asthma symptoms in some people.

  • Pet hair and dander, like cat hair, can fly in the air and land on many places in the room.

  • Fur and dander can stick to things like bath mats, towels, and other fabrics.

 

Pet Hair and Dander: How to avoid or reduce this trigger:

  • If allergic to pets, best to remove them from the home.

  • Keep furry pets out of bedrooms.

  • Limit furry pets to one area of the home.

  • Wash furry pets often.
targets.hint: I’m soft but shed all over

postText:
Aerosol Sprays and strong odors (like perfume, hairspray, and cleaning products) can be an inhaled irritant and trigger asthma symptoms for some people with asthma.

  • Using a lot of perfumes and scented body sprays can leave a strong smell in the room.

 

Aerosol Sprays: How to avoid or reduce this trigger:

  • Avoid using sprays.

  • Avoid products with strong smells.

  • Limit the amount of perfume used around people with asthma.

  • Air out the room after using perfume.
targets.Name: Perfume
targets.hint: I smell nice but leave fumes behind

postText:
Aerosol Sprays and strong odors like perfume, hairspray, and cleaning products can trigger asthma symptoms for some people with asthma.

  • Hair spray can stay in the air long after you use it and be an inhaled irritant.

 

Aerosol Sprays: How to avoid or reduce this trigger:

  • Avoid using aerosol sprays.

  • Avoid products with strong odors.

  • When using hairspray, open windows and air out the room.
targets.Name: Hairspray
targets.hint: I go in your hair, but also your air

postText:
Dust Mites are found in rugs. 

  • Dust mites can be an allergy trigger for some people with asthma.

  • Dust mites are so tiny they can’t be seen with the eye.

  • They live in items made of thick fibers like bedding, carpets, pillows, sofas, rugs and stuffed toys. 

  • Dust mites live and multiply in high humidity.

 

Dust Mites: How to avoid or reduce this trigger:

  • Replace large rugs with a small washable rug or mat.

  • Wash small area rugs often with hot water and dry on high heat.

  • If you can’t take out the rugs, use a vacuum cleaner with a high efficiency filter (HEPA) weekly.

  • Keep humidity level in home under 50%.
targets.Name: Rug
targets.hint: I keep your floor dry after a bath

postText:
Strong odors and fumes from Bleach and other common cleaning products and detergents can be an inhaled trigger for some people with asthma.

  • Using full strength bleach causes very strong fumes that stay in the air.

  • Using cleaning products in a room with closed windows can make smells stronger and stay longer.

 

Strong Odors: How to avoid or reduce this trigger:

  • Do not use full strength cleaning products when directions say to dilute with water.

  • Clean when the person with asthma is not in the area.

  • Open windows, doors or use a fan to move the air when cleaning.

  • Air out the room after cleaning.
targets.Name: Clorox
targets.hint: I make things clean, but my smell is very strong

postText:
Aerosol Sprays and strong scents (like perfume, air fresheners, and cleaning products) can be an inhaled irritant and trigger asthma symptoms for some people with asthma.

  • While they smell nice, air fresheners may be causing breathing problems.

  • Fumes from sprays can stay in the air for a long time.

 

Aerosol Sprays: How to avoid or reduce this trigger:

  • Avoid using aerosol sprays.

  • Avoid cleaning products that have strong odors.

  • Clean when the person with asthma is not in the area.

  • Air out the room after cleaning.
targets.Name: Febreze
targets.hint: When you spray, in the air my fumes stay

postText:
Molds, fungi or spores that live on surfaces sometimes can’t be seen with the eye. These spores can go into the air and be breathed in.

  • Mold can be an allergy trigger and can cause symptoms to flare for some people with asthma.

  • A dripping sink can create a wet place for mold to grow.

 

 

Mold: How to avoid or reduce this trigger:

  • Fix water leaks.

  • Keep indoor humidity under 50%.

  • Limit use of humidifiers or vaporizers as they can cause indoor moisture and mold growth.
targets.Name: SinkM
targets.hint: If you let water drip, I can grow

postText:
Molds, fungi or spores that live on surfaces are sometimes so tiny they can’t be seen with the eye. These spores can go into the air and be breathed in.

  • Mold can be an allergy trigger and can cause symptoms to flare for some people with asthma.

  • The outside of a toilet tank that is wet all the time can be a place that mold can grow.

 

Mold: How to avoid or reduce this trigger:

  • Fix water leaks.

  • Open the door, windows, or use a fan to remove steam.

  • Keep indoor humidity under 50%.

  • Wipe down a damp toilet tank often. Clean and remove mold as soon as it is seen.
targets.Name: Toilet
targets.hint: I can grow behind leaking objects
